prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We have used the enhanced capabilities of the ALMA correlator to observe simultaneously a number of molecular transitions in band 3. We have set 12 spectral window units with bandwidth 58.5 MHz (198 km/s) and spectral resolution of 141 kHz (0.48 km/s), after spectral averaging.
- Requested spectral resolution: The HCN, HCO+ lines observed with single-dish telescopes and interferometers (see Figure 2 as an example) show spectral lines with linewidths of about 5-10 km/s. We are interested in velocity gradients due to accretion channels that can be up to 2-3 km/s (corresponding to mass accretion rates of around 10^-3 Msun/yr, as obtained with the 3D radiative transfer models). Therefore, we need to be able to resolve changes in velociy of about 2 km/s. The requested spectral resolution of 0.5 km/s is sufficient to sample the velocity gradients and the line shapes with more than 4 spectral resolution elements, allowing therefore a proper analysis of the data. We note, that the hyperfine structure of the HCN(1-0) line is not a problem to analyze the gas kinematics, since we will take into account the line splitting when creating velocity field maps, and in the 3D radiative transfer modeling.
- Requested bandwidth: The exention of the lines in velocity is only of a few tens of km/s (for HCN and HCO+ we expect the largest velocity range to be about 50-60 km/s, due to the presence of high-velocity outflowing gas in the regions). A total bandwidth of about 200 km/s is enough to properly cover the whole velocity range, and still have enough line-free channels to determine the continuum level.
- Requested species (and continuum): The 12 spectral window units have been selected to cover different transitions relevant for the scientific goals of this proposal. In particular, each spectral unit covers one of the following transitions: HCN, H13CN, HC15N HCO+, H13CO+ HN13C, H15NC NH2D, SiO, CH3CCH, C2H, and H42alpha
We are also using a 1.8 GHz broad bandwidth to measure the continuum emission at 3mm.
In order to reduce the data rate, we have considered to spectral average the data. The spectral resolution (0.48 km/s) requested above is the result of this final spectral average.

We request an angular resolution of 1.4 arcsec, and a maximum recoverable angular scale (LAS) of 40 arcsec. The total field of view requested is 120x120 arcsec^2, and therefore a mosaic of 17 pointings.
- Requested angular resolution, and largest angular scale: Previous SMA observations at 0.8 mm, with a 2.5-arcsec beam, reveal a number of dense cores with sizes of a few arcsec (2000-4000 AU, at the corresponding distance of 1.3 kpc). These dense cores are embeded in dense clumps with sizes of a few tens of arcsec (25000-50000 AU). Our main goal is to characterize how accretion occurs between clumps and cores, and therefore we need to be sensitive to structures with sizes between 2000 AU and 50000 AU. At distance of 1.3 kpc, these spatial scales correspond to angular scales of 1.5 arcsec to 38 arcsec.
We have run some ALMA-simulations using the simobserve task within CASA, and confirmed that the configuration C36-3 results in an angular resolution of about 1.4 arcsec for our source declination. The maximum recoverable scale of this configuration is only 25 arcsec, we therefore request ACA observations to be sensitive to largest structures up to 40 arcsec. We note that the accretion channels that we expect to detect are elongated structures with typical extensions of a few 0.1 pc (20000 AU, or 15 arcsec).
- Requested field of view: The SMA observations shown in Figure 3 (Scientific Justification) cover only a small area centered on the main cluster, but clearly do not include the dense clump where the cluster is embedded. The typical extension of the clump (full-width at half-maximum) is of about 80 arcsec. We therefore ask to map an area of 120x120 arcsec^2, covering the extension of the clump, and the cluster seen previously with the SMA. At the frequency of about 90 GHz, this results in 17 pointings with Nyquist sampling.

The main goal is the detection of the HCN(1-0) and HCO+(1-0) lines at 3 mm, including their isotopologues. The requested sensitivity is 6.3 mJy (or 0.5 K) per 0.5-km/s channel, to reach S/N > 4.
- Line observations sensitivity: Previous observations of different HCN (and isotopologues) transitions towards NGC6334-I result in line intensities that vary between 5 and 12 K (with single-dish telescopes: MOPRA, APEX, Herschel). In particular the HCN(1-0) line has an intensity of 10 K (in a 38-arcsec beam), while the HCN(4-3) line has an intensity of 12 K (in a 18-arcsec beam). Similarly, interferometric observations with the SMA result in line intensities of the HCN(4-3) transition of 5-15 K depending on the dense core (in a 2.5-arcsec beam). With the proposed ALMA resolution (1.4 arcsec), we expect line intensities for the HCN(1-0) transition similar to (only slightly lower than) the intensities observed with the SMA for the HCN(4-3) transition, therefore we expect lines as bright as 4-13 K, or 50-165 mJy/beam, without considering any beam-dilution effect in the single-dish observations that could enhance the final intensity of the lines when observed with ALMA. For HCO+, the line intensity of the (1-0) transition as detected with MOPRA (38-arcsec beam) is slightly higher than the HCN(1-0). Therefore, we expect similar line intensities for the HCO+ (and isotopologues) transitions.
In addition to the dense condensations, we expect extended emission tracing "accretion channels" that is expected to be about 5 times weaker than the strongest cores, as revealed in the similar region G33.92+0.11 (Liu et al 2015). This sets the intensity of this accretion channels in a level of around 2.6 K (or 30 mJy/beam).
In order to detect lines with intensities above 30 mJy/beam with a signal-to-noise ratio higher than 4, we plan to reach a sensitivity of 6.3 mJy (or 0.5 K). This sensitivity has to be reached within a channel of 0.5 km/s (necessary to trace changes in velocity of a few km/s; see below).
Our spectral setup contains other interesting lines such as NH2D, H42a, CH3CCH, SiO that if detected will be used to better describe the physical properties of the science target. For those lines with observations already available (e.g., H42a, SiO with MOPRA) we have compared the line intensities with the HCN and HCO+ line intensities: These lines are typically a factor 2-4 weaker than HCN or HCO+, corresponding to line intensities of around 2-4 K (or 25-50 mJy/beam, in the ALMA observations). The emission of these lines is expected to be compact, and therefore, beam dilution effects may improve their detection in the ALMA observations.
- Continuum observations sensitivity: The 0.8 mm continuum maps obtained with the SMA (2.5-arcsec beam) reveal cores with peak intensities in the range 0.5-4 Jy/beam. We have converted this continuum intensity at 345 GHz to the expected continuum intensity at 90GHz assuming only a dust contribution with a (conservative) spectral index "beta" of 2: therefore, we have the relation Flux_90GHz = Flux_345GHz*(90/345)^(4), which results in an expected continuum peak intensity of 2-18 mJy/beam. Our correlator setup (see below), includes a broad 1.8 GHz band for continuum observations, that will result in a rms noise level of 0.05 mJy: good enough to detect the dust continuum cores, and the dust extended emission, with signal-to-noise ratios higher than 100. The bright sources will be used to self-calibrate the data of both continuum and line emission.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The formation of high-mass stars is one of the major topics of astrophysical research, in particular the process of accretion from large-scale clouds to small-scale cores. With this proposal we aim at characterizing this process by observing three highly-fragmented massive clumps that lie in the NGC6334 star forming complex. Our previous studies show large-scale velocity gradients and mass flows of 10^-3 Msun/yr at 1-pc scales. Detailed interferometric observations, show similar levels of accretion onto the different cores at 1000-AU scales. What is the link between the two scales? How is the mass transported from 1-pc to 1000-AU scales? What is the role of the magnetic field? We plan to answer these questions by observing HCN, HCO+ and other tracers: (i) ALMA high-fidelity images will permit to search for 'accretion channels' that connect the cloud/clump with the cores; (ii) The spatial distribution and line shapes (containing information of the accretion) will be modeled with a 3D radiative transfer pipeline developed by us; (iii) The HCO+/HCN ratio, as a probe of the magnetic field, will complement the already available information on the magnetic field in this region.
